general.description: Formula 1 (F1) is the highest class of single-seater auto racing, sanctioned by the Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile (FIA). It features a series of races called Grands Prix held worldwide on circuits and public roads.

origins.first_race: The first F1 World Championship race was held at Silverstone, UK, on May 13, 1950.
origins.early_era: Initially dominated by manufacturers like Alfa Romeo, Ferrari, and Maserati.

milestones.event: Introduction of the downforce concept to F1 cars.
McLaren won 15 out of 16 races in a season with Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost.
Introduction of new safety measures after the tragic deaths of Ayrton Senna and Roland Ratzenberger.
New regulations introduced, focusing on ground effect aerodynamics and closer racing.

general.description: F1 cars are high-performance, open-wheel, single-seater vehicles engineered for maximum speed and performance, capable of exceeding 370 km/h (230 mph).
general.fuel: Sustainable E10 fuel (10% ethanol, 90% fossil fuel blend)

features: Front and rear wings to generate downforce
Complex bargeboards and sidepods to control airflow

types: Soft (C1-C5 compound range for different grip levels)

technology.DRS: Drag Reduction System to aid overtaking
technology.ERS: Energy Recovery System to recover kinetic and heat energy
technology.telemetry: Real-time data transmission to teams for analysis
